awd_titl_txt: Lookit: Online interface for large-scale developmental studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Studies of how infants learn and how their cognitive abilities change across development are important endeavors being undertaken at many universities across the country.  This research depends largely on parents who have the time and resources to travel with their children to campus research laboratories to volunteer to participate in studies.  These volunteer parents are invaluable contributors to research, however they represent only a small segment of society.  Many families have dual-earner parents, lack easy transportation to campuses, or live far away from any research university, limiting their opportunities to participate in studies. This limits the size of the pool of volunteers and also the generalizability of the research results.  The goal of this research project is to develop a tool for online testing that can take place in infants' homes at parents' convenience and to test the tool to ensure that results commonly found in laboratory studies can be replicated through online testing.  

The online laboratory that Dr. Schulz and her research team propose to develop will be accessed through a website called "Lookit". The site will allow families all over the world to participate in scientific research about cognitive development.  Families will access Lookit through their web browser and can choose among available 5-10 minute studies.  Parents who choose to participate will give verbal authorization via webcam and their children's responses (ranging from looking behavior to pointing to verbal responses) will be recorded.  At the end of the study, parents can choose whether to transmit the video files to a secure server in the MIT Early Childhood Cognition Lab.  Lookit will thus enable large-scale participation. The web platform will be validated by replicating six established developmental findings children 4 months through 5 years of age.  Once validated, the tool will be made generally available to the cognitive development research community.

Lookit will reduce many traditional barriers to research, including the difficulty of running studies involving large sample sizes, narrow age ranges, special populations, and socioeconomically diverse populations.  Lookit will also provide a new outlet for STEM education and outreach: a resource page will provide information about cognitive development in a format accessible to the layperson.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Studying what babies and young children start off knowing, and how they learn, can help researchers better understand human cognition, improve education, and treat developmental disorders. Traditionally, this research depends heavily on parents and children coming in to campus research labs to volunteer in the studies. Because the lab visit is a substantial time commitment for both the family and researcher, and studies generally take place on university campuses during work hours, this system limits how much data can be collected and which families can participate.

To enable more representative and larger-scale participation, we developed an online lab called “Lookit” where families all over the world can take part in research about cognitive development. Any parent can create an account on Lookit (https://lookit.mit.edu) and register their child to select from currently running studies. Participation takes place in the home, at the family’s convenience, without the need for any scheduling. Parents who choose to participate complete short activities in their web browser with their infant or young child, while webcam video is recorded. This video is sent to the lab so that researchers can analyze children’s responses – for instance, whether an infant spends more time looking at a video on the left or right of the screen, or how a preschooler answers a question. Parents make a verbal statement at the start of the study that they agree to participate, and can choose at the end of the study how their video data may be used. 

We first tested this tool to make sure that responses observed in laboratory studies could be reliably measured online as well. We validated the online platform by running three studies based on published results that used different age ranges (infancy through 5 years old) and types of responses (looking time, looking preference, and verbal responses). Our results were similar to published work and demonstrated that we could reliably collect and code these responses. We then focused on making this approach available to the developmental psychology community by building tools for researchers to easily write and manage their studies.

Lookit reduces many traditional practical barriers to research. Lookit will enable large-scale participation in developmental research by making it much easier for parents to participate and researchers to recruit interested families. This allows researchers to do more reproducible work and measure effects more precisely. It will especially help to enable multiple-session studies, which can provide insight into differences among children and the effects of educational approaches, and work with special populations, narrow age ranges, and newborns. It will also allow broader participation in research, making it easier for both underrepresented families (e.g., those headed by single parents or far from university labs) and potential researchers without access to a child lab (e.g., early childhood educators or nurses) to take part.


Last Modified: 10/03/2017
Modified by: Laura E Schulz
